description.text:
Better version of the card holder I submitted yesterday. When I get home I'll show how I made it and my logic behind some of the stuff. Hope the customizer view is helpful and fairly self explanatory

edit 4/5 8:45 PM
So it turns out if you set the $fn value high and have a lot of circles you get a lot of errors.... sorry about that.. It worked on my computer and just took a while. SHOULD be fixed now

So this all started with this mockup drawing Step 2:

From there I made a mockup in inventor (love that program!) and tried to make the name part customizable in openscad. It worked! I was excited so I posted it, and it is what this was re-mixed from.

Step 3:

The scad file for this is based off of advise I received which was to make more modular based code so I can recycle code bits easier. (aka the more I make the less I have to re-make) There are still a few bugs with some of the advanced options so I hope to have a patch out for those soon. Once I squash those bugs I'll explain the code line for line.

title: HBP Wedge Removal Tool
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: A wedge shaped tool that can be used to help separate objects from the HBP. Razors often catch the Kapton tape ending up with having to replace the tape on the HBP. This tool doesn't damage the tape. If you have trouble getting an edge, then start off a corner of the object with the razor, then finish off removing the object with this removal tool. I find this razor holder to be the best: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:4210 Print at 100% fill, so that it will be strong. This tool can also double up for mixing glue and smoothing things etc. Depending on how much abuse you put this tool through, the first (thinest) layer may get chewed up. I generally trim this first layer when this happens and continue to use the tool.

comments.text: Simple and effective. I use a metal tool to lift an edge, and this wedge generally can do the rest. On larger prints, use two wedges  =-O
comments.author: Busybotz

comments.text: Worked great thanks!
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Most makerbotters already have many of these they dont know about...
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: I hope this works! I am printing one now :)
comments.author: eried

comments.text: So on raft printing I've found wedge tool is all you need.  On raftless, if you are pushing into the surface on the first layer,  start off a corner with the razor tool referenced in this print and then remove with the wedge tool.  With this technique I've gone from having to change my kapton tape every couple of prints due to cutting it accidentally with the razor to managing 20 prints without having to change the tape yet.   Just make sure you don't have bubbles in your tape, otherwise you can catch them with the razor.
comments.author: eried

Simplify3D Tool Change Script

This script is inspired from the Script thread over at the Simplify3D forum, specifically the post by user blaknite7.

My version of Simplify3D doesn't parse the place holder variables for tool temperatures in the tool change script, so I used my absolute printing temperatures there instead.

The clear benefit of this approach is near full elimination of oozing and drips on the print. The drawback is that print time on multicolour layers are near doubled in printing time. Be warned :)

There are two versions here of the script, I've used the M133 script on my Sailfish firmware Wanhao Duplicator 4S printer. This is because my printer doesn't honor the M109 command. So I use two M104 commands followed by a M133 command.

The second version uses a M109 command as designed by blaknite7.

The model I have printed to test this script, and which is used in the illustration is made by MakeALot and is called two colour calibration cubes. I highly recomend using those objects to calibrate your dual nozzle printing. The objects enclosed here are just dummies :)

M109 Script

; ******* Tool chance script start *******
G1 X0 Y40 F4000 ; Move out of the way while it stabilises active tool temp. 
{IF NEWTOOL=0}; RIGHT Extruder is active (T0)
{IF NEWTOOL=0}M104 S165 T1; Cool inactive extruder to 165c (T1)
{IF NEWTOOL=0}M109 S210 T0; Heat active extruder to 210c (T0). 
{IF NEWTOOL=1}; LEFT Extruder is active (T1)
{IF NEWTOOL=1}M104 S165 T0; Cool inactive extruder to 165c (T0)
{IF NEWTOOL=1}M109 S210 T1; Heat active extruder to 210c (T1). 
; ******* Tool chance script end *******

There are two things to change here, the coordinates where oozing can happen, and your print temperature.

M133 Script

; ******* Tool chance script start *******
G1 X0 Y40 F4000 ; Move out of the way while it stabilises active tool temp. 
{IF NEWTOOL=0}; RIGHT Extruder is active
{IF NEWTOOL=0}M104 S165 T1; Cool inactive extruder to 165c (T1)
{IF NEWTOOL=0}M104 S210 T0; Heat active extruder to 210c (T0). 
{IF NEWTOOL=0}M133 T0; Stabilise T0 temperature
{IF NEWTOOL=1}; LEFT Extruder is active
{IF NEWTOOL=1}M104 S165 T0; Cool inactive extruder to 165c (T0)
{IF NEWTOOL=1}M104 S210 T1; Heat active extruder to 210c (T0). 
{IF NEWTOOL=1}M133 T1; Stabilise T1 temperature
; ******* Tool chance script end *******

Same things needs changing here, the coordinates where oozing can happen, and your print temperature.

Attributions

  • blaknite7 for the original idea and first version of the Tool Change Script.
  • MakeALot two colour calibration cubes to test this script with.

description.text: A 2 part soap dish with separate container and holder.  The container has 4 feet that needs to be glued on with super glue.  The container is designed not to drain so that it doesn't ruin the material underneath.
Use 0.20mm layer height.  Use a raft for the feet to help with removal.  Scale the feet smaller if it doesn't fit into the holes.  Use superglue to attach the feet to the holder.

This is a coin with the COD Zombie's group 935 logo on it. This can be printed in one or two colours. I will make a key ring version later. The images shown are print at 200% scale. I had issues with my slicer as parts of the model are just too small to print on my 0.4mm nozzle.

There are two version of the model. 1 colour and 2 colour.
The 1 colour model is to print the whole model in one colour and with 1 extruder. The 2 colour version has 2 models so the final model can be in 2 colours.

title: Tripod Cam-Lock Repair (Modified) for Manfrotto Digi 718B tripod

description.text:
After surviving the sandy cliffs of Dogon Country in Mali, the crowds of downtown Dhaka and many rides strapped to the back of a moped in Vietnam, our camera tripod finally broke during a photoshoot at a Boston medical center. Specifically, we broke one of the cam-locks on the tripod legs. In removing the broken latch, we broke another latch on the same leg.

We were about to dive into some tedious CAD work when we discovered that frubino had already created models of our broken parts. Hooray Thingiverse!

This remix adapts frubino's design to our Manfrotto Digi 718B camera tripod. Using Autodesk Inventor's Direct Modify tool, we made the inner walls of the medium and the large latch housings wider all around by 0.5mm for a sliding fit--thanks frubino for posting IGS files!. We also created new thinner pads for inside the cam, which allowed us to fit the cam hinge pin though both the printed part and the original thumb-lock.

This is my Delta project.
Single E3D type/J-Head or homemade/ hotend - 0.3, 0.4, 0.5 etc mm nozzle, bowden type extruder.
400W PC ATX PSU(Fortron 400PNR in my case).
Electronics - Mega2560 + RAMPs 1,4 + Full_Graphic_Smart_LCD_Controller + 4 NEMA 17 motors. Malrin Fimware.
Working area with 210x200x4mm glass - cylinder r=83 mm/h~250 mm;
Manual control for 40 mm fan for hotend/always ON by default/ and manual control for 30 mm fan duct with potentiometer. Can be used http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1337200 for e3dV5/6 - it will be probably better, than my version for cooling.
Voltmeter.

Can be used any type of bowden type extruder with offset of 50 mm for mounting holes.
Can be used simple 2560 bracket or box for electronics. When using box - put Mega 2560 first, screw it and then the RAMPs pcb.
File for laser cutting in AutoCad 2013+ format.
Left and Right panels are identical, but if You use left side for electronics and PSU, maybe longer extender cable for LCD controller will be needed.
Do not build without side panels - it will be unstable.
Video - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xW9SEJ_wxPo&feature=youtu.be

26.10.2016
Finally I manage to find ~150 Euros for material and laser cutting. After assembly find some minor errors, so reuploaded LC file with corrections and added .stl file #26, which is additional bracket (u need 6 of these) for better stability of the panels. Still have to read about calibrating dome/plate effects with these deltas ;)

Thing is ready. May be will add holder for proximity sensor in the future.

08.11.2016
Still calibrating... Definitely this will be my 1st and last delta printer...
Added 3 photos of the completed printer.
Video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KNYZsMnecfI

TRENDi Maker V3

description.text:
Parameter driven openscad effector for bltouch mounting. Lets you choose the effector width, rotation of the hotend hole, bltouch offset, bltouch rotation, arm length, arm width, etc.

Version 0.1

I printed an effector I downloaded from here earlier today to try and connect my bltouch but it didn't quite fit my e3d v6 in the clamp so I decided to have a go at making my own in sketch up... after that failed I googled a lot and decided to modify vitaminrad's awesome work.

I haven't printed it yet.. will do that tomorrow.

Just tweaked it a little bit so the cable hole points towards the bltouch so it's wires can hopefully go through the same hole.

Update for Version 0.3: I printed 0.2 today ... the nut holes are a bit small and the whole effector is probably a bit slim (especially the clamps).

To do:

1, Print out version 0.3
2, Keep calibrating my printer.. I really am a noob and the quality of prints I'm getting so far is really bad.
3, Investigate a way to make the clamp hold a fan somehow for cooling the print (I'm having lots of trouble with bridging.. I might have to try and print with supports)

Update version 0.4

I printed out version 0.3... and then cracked it while screwing in the rods.. so I've changed it and created 0.4 .. I've made it a bit smaller as well...

Still trying to think of a nice way to mount a print cooling fan....

Update version 0.5

I printed out 0.4 and have mounted it.. I'm pretty happy with it but the clamp is a bit too thick for my screws so I've slimmed it down and made version 0.5.

Update version 0.9.1

Lots of changes... mostly the optional fan.. and moving the e3d down lower so that the normal e3d cooling fan can be mounted the correct way up.

Update version 0.9.2

I haven't printed this yet... hopefully it solves my issues with the previous ones. The fans are now rotated so they dont reduce the print volume by no longer being in line with the delta frame.

Update version 0.9.5

Not happy with how the fans mount on this at all... I printed it.. it's working but it sucks (the fan part).
All of my complaints are with the fan mounts...
Barely enough clearance.. fan mounts are super hard to print nicely.
Most likely going to switch to centrifugal fan(s) for the next version.

WELDING
“Welding and Women, both start with W. Coincidence? I think not!”

Our goal:
To introduce girls to a non-traditional career: welding

How we will achieve this:
by creating a guide for girls who want to try welding as an activity

What is welding?
Welding is the most economical and efficient way to join metals permanently. It is the only way of joining two or more pieces of metal to make them act as a single piece. Welding is vital to our economy. It is said that over 50% of the products produced from the U.S.A, is related to welding in one way or another.
Nearly everything we use in our daily life is welded or made by equipment that is welded. Welders help build metal products from coffee pots to skyscrapers. In construction, welders are building the world; extending subways, building bridges, and helping to improve the environment by building pollution control devices. The use of welding is practically unlimited.

Safety in welding:
The general hazards of welding include impact, penetration, harmful dust, smoke, fumes, heat and light radiation. Welding “smoke” is a mixture of very fine particles (fumes) and gases. Many of the substances in the smoke can be extremely toxic. The intense heat of welding and sparks can cause burns. Eye injuries have resulted from contact with hot slag and metal chips. The intense light associated with welding can cause eye damage. Ultraviolet light from an arc can cause “welder’s flash” and also burns. There is also a danger of electric shock. If combustible or flammable materials are nearby, the heat and sparks produced by welding can cause fires or explosions. The use of compressed gas cylinders poses some unique hazards to the welder.
Before any welding is conducted outside of a designated welding area, a responsible individual must inspect the area and identify precautions to be taken preferably on a written Hot Works permit. Fire extinguishers must be ready for immediate use. A fire watch lasting at least 30 minutes after the welding or cutting operations is required if more than a minor fire might develop. All combustibles must be moved 35 feet away or properly protected or shielded.
Prohibited areas for welding include:
• Areas unauthorized by management
• Areas where sprinklers are impaired
• Areas in explosive atmospheres
• Areas near storage of large quantities of readily ignitable materials

Safety equipment for welding:
Eye and face protection:
Proper eye and face protection for welding safety includes: A helmet, goggles and safety glasses or combination of these are acceptable protection in various applications. All filter lenses and plates must meet the test for transmission of radiant energy prescribed in ANSI/ISEA Z87.1-2015, American National Standard for Occupational and Educational Personal Eye and Face Protection Devices.

Protective clothing:
Clothing should cover all visible skin and be made of cotton, wool, or flame resistant material to prevent skin burns caused by sparks, spatter or radiation. Covering all parts of the body is recommended to protect against ultraviolet and infrared ray flash burn (i.e.sunburn).
Dark clothing works best to reduce reflection under a faceshield. Heavy materials, such as wool clothing, heavy cotton or leather, are preferred as they resist deterioration.
The ANSI standard requires all welders and cutters to wear protective flame-resistant gloves, such as leather welder’s gloves, which provide the heat resistance needed for welding. A gauntlet cuff offers additional arm protection. Insulated linings should be used to help protect areas exposed to high radiant energy.
Other protective clothing for welding safety may include durable, flame-resistant aprons made of leather or other suitable materials to provide protection to the front of the body when additional protection against sparks and radiant energy is needed.
Ventilation:
Ventilation refers to changes of room air as often as necessary to prevent welders and other workers from breathing high levels of airborne contaminants. Ventilation is a means of providing adequate breathing air, and it must be provided for all welding, cutting, brazing and related operations. Adequate ventilation depends on the following factors:
• Volume and configuration of the space where the welding operations occur
• Number and type of operations that are generating contaminants
• Natural air flow rate where operations are taking place
• Location of the welders’ and other workers’ breathing zones in relation to contaminants or sources

Proper ventilation can be obtained either naturally or mechanically. Natural ventilation is considered sufficient for welding and brazing operations if the work area meets these requirements:
• Space of more than 10,000 square feet is provided per welder
• A ceiling height of more than 16 feet
• Welding is not done in a confined space
• Welding space does not contain partitions, balconies or structured barriers that obstruct cross ventilation

If your specific operation does not fall within the natural ventilation guidelines, mechanical ventilation will be required. Mechanical ventilation options generally fall into two basic categories. The first is a low-vacuum system, which takes large volumes of air at low velocities. This system consists of hoods positioned at a distance from the work area. The hood and housing may have to be repositioned by the worker to get maximum benefit from this means of ventilation. Hoods generally remove the fumes and contaminated air through ducting and exhaust the contaminants to the outdoors. Hoods should be placed as near as practical to the work and should provide effective air flow with a velocity of 100 linear feet (30 meters) per minute at its most remote distance from the point of welding. Processes where low-vacuum systems work best are arc air gouging and arc cutting.
Another category of mechanical ventilation is a high-vacuum system. This system consists of a close-range extractor aimed at capturing and extracting fumes as near to the work as possible. Fume extractors often have an immediate area of welding. By removing a small volume of air at a high velocity, the potentially hazardous materials are effectively removed before reaching the welder’s breathing zone. These systems often are equipped with a fan that pulls the contaminants into a filtration system, with a high-efficiency particulate absolute (HEPA) filter or combination of HEPA filter and prefilter and then recirculates the clean air back into the work area. Advantages of high-vacuum systems are greater flexibility for job adaptation, more efficient means of fume removal and greater visibility to the welder due to reduced clouds of fumes and vapors being created.

For more information on welding safety and regulations, see :
https://www.osha.gov/pls/oshaweb/owadisp.show_document?p_table=STANDARDS&p_id=9853
http://www.aws.org/standards/page/safety-health-fact-sheets
Age appropriate activities:

• Interview professional welder
• Visit a functioning business that uses welding often
• Visit your local maker space
• Use a 3D design program (sketch-up or a free program will work, be sure to tell an adult and get their permission before downloading anything) to make a model (if possible build it)
• Build the design provided (‘The Alcatraz Bird House’)

Some places to try welding:
Hilary teaches welding classes at the Houston Makerspace; we really appreciated her talking with our troop and helping some of us try welding! [email protected]

title: Wanhao I3 duplicator Y-Axis adjustable belt tension block

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/8cAjWgOZoTo

Printer:

Wanhao I3 Duplicator

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

23%

Notes:

You need
4 M3 X 5 mm hexagon set screws which lock the belt.
1 M3X 25 mm screw for putting tension between both parts.
1 M3 normal nut

  • First print the object and check the fitting of the small part sliding into the large part.
  • I printed them in PETG material. Depending of the tolerance of your printer you might need to rework the small part with sanding paper. Check if in the square hole in the large parts there are no remains of plastics.
  • DO NOT enlarge or drill the holes where the setscrews need to be fitted.
  • Drill the 3 mm hole in the large part with a 3 mm drill bit.
  • Drill the 3 mm hole that runs along the small part with a 3 mm drill bit.
  • Place the 3 mm nut in the correct place of the large part and with a M3 screw pull it in its correct place.
  • Remove the heat bed from the carrier
  • Turn the machine on its side so you can easily access the bottom.
  • Check how the belt runs/loops as you need to place it in the same way otherwise it will run in reverse!
  • Remove the screws that hold the belt ends.
  • Remove the two screws from the black metal part that is attached on the carrier plate.
  • Remove the zip ties from the belt.
  • Slide the belt in the correct way in the new large belt holder until you can see it through the 2 holes that will carry the setscrews and secure it with the two M3 x 5 mm hexagon set screws. You can use the 1.5 mm hexagon tool that comes with the machine. Do not overtighten the set screws!
  • Fix the large part to the carrier plate with the original M4 screws. If you used PLA and feel the fitting of the screws is tight use a 4 mm tapping tool first.
  • Now loop the belt in the correct way around the motor and idler pulley and mark the place where you have to cut the belt.
  • Now fit the belt in the small part until you can see it through the 2 holes that will carry the setscrews and secure it with the two M3 x 5 mm hexagon set screws. You can use the 1.5 mm hexagon tool that comes with the machine. Do not overtighten the set screws and make sure the part is not deformed!
  • Fit the small part in the large part and tighten up the large M3 screw until the belt is at correct tension. If the belt is loose when the large screw is fully tightened remove one tooth from the belt per try and error.
  • Turn the machine in its normal position.
  • Refit the heat bed and level it first before any print job.
  • Enjoy……………………………….printing and be happy.

title: FALCONER MK I - Nerf-Style Foam Dart Gauntlet

description.text:
10/05/16
NOTE: This version is outdated and I've learnt a lot since. Due to time constraints I won't be editing or updating these files much so be aware that while it will be cheaper for the electronics, you'll have to do more cleaning up work.

09/04/16
So small printers can handle all parts except the Back Base. As such I've split it down into Back Base 1 and Back Base 2, which can be solvent welded together. They're designed to split through the motor mount base so solvent welding may not be entirely necessary but for strength I'd recommend it!

07/04/16
After discussion in comments (see below) several things are under consideration.
The motors used are RM2 Solarbotics available at https://www.pololu.com/product/611 however it's recognised that the torque may not be sufficient for the ramrod system.
As such research will be done into geared and higher torque motors while trying to minimise the trade off of price, power requirements and control electronics.
The original design is meant to be accessible and as such I tried to avoid expensive motors and needing to buy and program control electronics, this may prove necessary in future iterations.
Also raised was the fact that some people have wide hands and arms. While this was designed with 80mm inner clearance horizontally that's a recognised issue and thought will be put to addressing it, keeping in mind it would be nice not to make the entire thing monstrously oversized. Perhaps, as was suggested, a mega dart version would be appropriate. Stay posted, MK II may be underway sooner than I anticipated!

Late 06/04/16
I AM SO KICKING MYSELF. I accidentally clicked "Publish" instead of save and view... Anyway I've done a quick botch job and uploaded the relevant videos to youtube, check below for the links to see how the thing works and I'll have a video out on assembly in a day or two so stay posted!
06/04/16
This is a fully automatic flywheel style gauntlet designed to fire 22 Nerf Elite darts. It is made to house 3 Solarbotics RM2 motors; 2 flywheel and 1 to run the ramrod mechanism.
The entire design can be 3D printed with relative ease and the STLs should all be pre-oriented for printing (always double check they're flat on bed etc). It is all assembled with M3 screws, maximum length of 15mm.
All holes are made with 3mm and 2.5mm diameters for the screws to grab onto.

I have provided a total of 3 videos on the subject, two documenting my design and how it works and the third showing assembly steps.

The design is ambidextrous and the wiring of the control mechanism is up to the end user though personally I like the ring option as I mention in my video.

A quick circuit drawing is provided with the images depicting two parallel flywheel motors in parallel with the ramrod motor, both with control switches.

Hi!
I've allowed some space between the moving parts, a brief sanding down would probably help anyway! Don't forget that lithium grease is common in lots of these toy guns.
The bore diameter of the bracelet part is 80mm and is padded down to arm size, if that's too small for you I'll put my mind to making a larger/openable version that doesn't interfere with the mechanism.
Hmmm as for minimum clearance... A 200*200 bed would be absolutely fine, I'll get back to you with the largest dimension this evening (currently sitting in a materials and manufacture tutorial) and I'm sure it could, especially given the fact the rotation ratchet system is printed separately. I'll definitely take a look at that!
Motors, can do! Solarbotics RM2 here: https://www.pololu.com/product/611
As for springs, I'm not so sure myself! I don't have any available with me, that's an area I'll be interested in testing further, made easier by the fact the spring isn't permanently attached. I'll be looking into sourcing some suitable spring data however without being able to test the torque output of the motors it's a bit hit and miss.
Really you can use it without a spring, it's just there to make sure the ramrod stops in the right place!

Sure, you have every reason to be suspicious, I would be too. I'm a Product Design and Engineering student; I don't have access to a printer or the money to afford a 3Dhub print of every idea that goes through my head.
I don't claim that this will work perfectly and honestly I wish I could make multiple prints and perfect the product however the theory is all correct. Take a look at the parts yourself for printability; some aren't as friendly however I've taken every effort to design them for maximum printability.
Functionality? Again, apart from theory based on everything I've learnt, I have no physical testing of the model.

Simple dolly with a GoPro-Camera mount to be used with one single rope or cable with a diameter up to 12 mm.
It was originally designed to be hoisted up the topping lift or backstay on a sailing yacht but can be used on any rope or cable as long as it is not vertical or close to vertical.
Of course it may swing. That can hardly be avoided with only one cable.

You need to print:

  • 1x set of chassis (2 parts in one file or see separate left/right-File); The left and right parts are different!
  • 2x wheel
  • 2x set of screw and nut (file containing the screw and the nut or see single files for screw and nut)

You additionally need:
1x M5 nut

The chassis needs to be printed with support. It is only little waste that is printed but the overhanging part of the camera mount needs the support.
The screw should not need support. At least for me it worked fine without.
The wheel definitely needs no support.

I am not sure if all types of M5 nuts fit the hole in the stl-File. If yours doesn't, take the scad-File and change the value of the variable named 'nutwidth' right at the beginning of the file.

The dolly was already successfully tested with a standard tripod mount adapter and a heavier camera (Lumix DMC-FT5). See picture.
Just be sure to add an additional retrieval line to the lower end to hoist it down if not easily accessible. In slightly higher winds, the wind catch of the hoisting line may prevent the whole thing from sliding back!

Printer Brand:

MakerGear

Printer:

M2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

comments.text: Can you can explain how you hoist it up and down the backstay? Is it something that can be done easily?
comments.author: devdevdev

comments.text:
Hi
Hoisting up sometimes is easy, sometimes it is not. It really depends on the boat. If you have a single backstay and if you have the topping lift or main halyard available, it is quite easy. On a split backyard sometimes you may not be able to reach up to where it continues as one line.
Sometimes you also can run the dolly on the topping lift and hoist it up with the main halyard.
Sometimes a Spinnaker halyard can be used, just be careful if you use a line in the back of the boat that is actually directed forward because it may jam. Well, I a sure you now that.

title: Dell 924 Cartridge Holder Replacement Part
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
EDIT: Do not print this in PLA, it will just shatter and fill the printer full of plastic.

Someone gave me a Dell 924 a few years ago, I tried it recently and it promptly started burning. I found both of the clips had cracked from fatigue and the previous owner decided they would smash it to pieces instead of look closer and try something else.

This part may also fit other Dell branded printers.

This was the first spare part I had ever created in OpenSCAD. It seems to be working well so far. I thought I'd share it just in case anyone still has this printer and it didn't fill the scanner bed with smoke residue when the cartridge burned up. If I had noticed that this part wouldn't exist, oh well :)

You can use this part in a printer used in a commercial environment.

title: Bender Tool for electronic components
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Bender Tool for electronic components

This is a Remix of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1022337

The tool is now less likely to cause injuries and can bend Beside axial components, transistors / MOSFETS / (non axial) condensators / LEDs and any other thing that fits the slot. The axial component slots are given a small fillet,

The MOSFET slot has a chamfer & fillet so also components with a thinner wire can be bend to the desired angle. The obstruction in the middle is small enough, for TO-220 and both slots are wide enough for TO-92.

The Remix of the source file is included. The Remix Update is less high reducing print time and has a hole in it for easy use (nail not included).

Guidelines:
http://www.ipc.org/committee/drafts/1-13_d_7251WD1.pdf

comments.text:
Check out the new thingy remix for BIGGER electronic components.

remixed_from.author: Gyrobot
remixed_from.title: The Armadillo - A Case of Two Halves

description.text:
A nested pencil case, which locks using a pencil.
A ruler that can make more rulers out of pencils.
A pencil top connector, to construct geodesic shapes out of pencils. We like pencils!!! http://youtu.be/vTAA2c2JZcI http://www.gyrobot.co.uk
http://www.facebook.com/gyrobotuk

EDIT 14/09/13 : Enlarged pencil case loops and replaced stl. Print :
  • 2 x Pencil Case Halves.
    • Cable tie or PLA rivet together.
  • 2 x Rulers to make a press mould.
    • Insert pencil, press together in a vice and viola, a pencil ruler.
  • Zillions of Pencil Connectors (and pencils) to make a massive moonbase alpha.
    • Scale up or down to achieve correct fit around pencil.
    • All based on a standard pencil 7mmA/F x 190mm long.

comments.text:
Found this pencil case through the Colorfabb blog:
https://learn.colorfabb.com/school-kit/
Keep up the good work.
comments.author: Matsugawa

comments.text: Hi, the instructions call for cable ties or PLA rivets to hold the two halves together.

comments.text: I liked the dessing, it's very original, congratulations!!. i have tried  but after print I found near to impossible to open it, and it finally broke. Probably the problem is ABS, the hinges were stuck. I would suggest you make each cover separately, and then pass through a printed screw with some washers, but it woldn't be as funny.

comments.text: Sorry you had issues, this is a print in place object not one for multiple assembly, so the design will remain as is.

comments.text:
Great Design,
But do you have to extract the pencil-case shells from the stl file seperately. or can it be printed directly?

Hi Martin,
There is minimal assembly by having to cable tie / pla rivet each half together, however each half can be printed completely assembled, see the photo showing how it was printed on my build table + instructions tab.

title: Easily Removable Shopping Cart Token Customizer

description.text:
Very simple customizable shopping cart token. It is designed to be easily attached and detached from key chain and cheap/easy to print, depending on your settings somewhere in the $0.15 range.

This file is set for Canadian $1 coin.

This is a remix of (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1463169) as it didn't have an SCAD to fit other currencies.

author: MichiP

description.text:
I can't print true lens cap: it was smaller than and support was needed.
This cap requires no support material and fits after print in low res.

comments.text: I made 2 of these.  The first one I did as is and it was just a little too small.  It fits and will work but you cannot actually turn it to lock it on.  The second one I did at 1.5% larger and it is just a little too big.  It screws on but is a little looser than the ones that came with my other lenses.  Both are printed from PLA at 10% infill.
comments.author: Darkcheops

comments.text: Just printed this dust cap, ended-up a little smallish, probably some shrinkage over here.  With some dremeling taking off most of the internal shell, I got it to fit.  Printing another 1% larger.
